subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Grammar question: Demonstrative vs. nondemonstrative "that"
msgSnippet: That can be a conjunction: I wish that I had more money. On 4/23/2018 6:21 AM, Nathan Galt mailinglists@ngalt.com [Read_Alphabet] ... That can be a
messageBody:
"That" can be a conjunction: I wish that I had more money.

On 4/23/2018 6:21 AM, Nathan Galt mailinglists@... [Read_Alphabet] wrote:
 

On pages 16 and 17 of The Manual it says to spell “that” out fully (·they·at·tea) only when it’s used as a demonstrative, and to use ·they·tea otherwise.

I checked the Wikipedia page for demonstratives (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demonstrative>) and I’m pretty sure I know when “that” is used in a demonstrative context.

How can one use “that” in a nondemonstrative context, though?

Also, does anyone care to hazard a guess as to why Read would want to make the distinction in print?

"That" can be a conjunction: I wish that I had more money.

On 4/23/2018 6:21 AM, Nathan Galt mailinglists@... [Read_Alphabet] 
wrote:
>
> On pages 16 and 17 of The Manual it says to spell “that” out fully 
> (·they·at·tea) only when it’s used as a demonstrative, and to use 
> ·they·tea otherwise.
>
> I checked the Wikipedia page for demonstratives 
> (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demonstrative>) and I’m pretty sure I 
> know when “that” is used in a demonstrative context.
>
> How can one use “that” in a nondemonstrative context, though?
>
> Also, does anyone care to hazard a guess as to why Read would want to 
> make the distinction in print?
>
>

            <p>On pages 16 and 17 of The Manual it says to spell “that”
              out fully (·they·at·tea) only when it’s used as a
              demonstrative, and to use ·they·tea otherwise.<br>
              <br>
              I checked the Wikipedia page for demonstratives
              (<a class="moz-txt-link-rfc2396E" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demonstrative"><https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demonstrative></a>) and
              I’m pretty sure I know when “that” is used in a
              demonstrative context.<br>
              <br>
              How can one use “that” in a nondemonstrative context,
              though?<br>
              <br>
              Also, does anyone care to hazard a guess as to why Read
              would want to make the distinction in print?</p>
          </div>
